intro: Acaena adenocarpa var. basiinermis, commonly known as the smooth burrplant, is a perennial shrub native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its dense, spiny foliage and small, yellowish flowers that bloom in spring. The plant produces spherical, woody fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind and animals. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and subalpine habitats. Due to its hardy nature, it is sometimes considered an invasive species in non-native regions.

The plant is adapted to the rugged terrain and variable weather patterns of the Andes. It plays an important ecological role in its native habitat by providing food and habitat for local wildlife.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena adenocarpa var. basiinermis was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the broader introduction of the Acaena genus for horticultural and ornamental purposes. It has since become naturalized in certain regions of New Zealand, particularly in coastal and disturbed habitats.
